docs.abstract: Dr. Eileen O'Reilly of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center responds to readers questions about pancreatic cancer.
docs.lead_paragraph: June 10, 4:41 p.m. | Updated Thanks for all your questions. See Dr. O'Reilly's responses in the Related Posts section, below. Additional responses will be coming soon.In this week's Science Times, Jane Brody, the Personal Health columnist, writes about the challenge of pancreatic cancer, an illness that is detected and treated at a potentially curable stage in fewer than 20 percent of those who have it. The disease, which became more common in recent decades with the rise in cigarette smoking, has also been linked to obesity, diabetes, lack of exercise, certain pesticides and chemicals and other factors. Some patients also have a family history of the disease.
docs.snippet: Dr. Eileen O'Reilly of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center responds to readers questions about pancreatic cancer.

headline.main: Greg Mankiw on the Soda Tax

docs.abstract: Is soda more like gasoline or tobacco?
docs.lead_paragraph: Greg Mankiw, the economist and blogger, had a column in the Sunday Times considering -- and expressing skepticism about -- a soda tax. In recent months, New York, Philadelphia and Washington have all considered imposing a tax on sodas and other artificially sweetened beverages. So far, none has done so.
docs.snippet: Is soda more like gasoline or tobacco?
